story:
WHY YOGA?

It's simple really.  I love yoga, and I love what it has done for me.  I want to help others experience that same joy and transformation.

 

When I started doing yoga about five years ago my life changed.  I began to love and respect my body in new ways.  I began seeing myself as someone who is strong, graceful and beautiful.  And I saw the transformation in my fellow classmates and knew that I must do this!  I must share what I have learned!  I must teach yoga!

 

WHAT CAN I DO WITH YOGA?

I believe this world can be transformed into a peaceful place of community and caring through love. And I believe yoga is a powerful tool for this transformation. It obviously helps physically, but the mental tranquility it offers is near miraculous.  There is a peace, a quiet...a me that I really love... as I move through life as a yogini.

 

My goal as a yoga teacher will be to share this beautiful gift with others by creating and facilitating workshops and retreats.  (I currently co-facilitate a fiber art workshop.  Being able to teach yoga will allow me to add another dimension of self exploration to this class.)

 

I also plan to volunteer my time to teaching yoga both 1:1 and in group settings to two populations I have served for the last 17 years--people with developmental disabilities and people who have experienced trauma in their lives.

 

WHAT DO I NEED?

I am registering for The Samarya Center’s Yoga Teacher Training.  This is an amazing non-profit committed to making yoga accessible to everyone.  The amount I originally thought I would need for the training is $3350.  

HOWEVER!!!!  GREAT NEWS!!!!  I applied for and was given the blessing of a scholarship and now what I need to raise is $1650 which must be paid in full by September 9th.  

This scholarship was such an amazing & surprising gift, I know I have just over 30 days to raise the dollars to make this dream come true....but I couldn't turn down this opportunity.  Most teacher training programs are between $3000-5000 buckaroos...and the cost has been an obstacle for several years.  I've wanted this for so long; it just feels like the right time.  So, I am considering this a lesson in overcoming my deeply ingrained "I can do it myself" story and putting this out into the big wild Universe to see what can happen.

 

WHAT YOU CAN DO?

Share my request with peeps you think may be interested in supporting my dream, wish on a falling star, bargain with a leprechaun, buy a winning lottery ticket and send a few dollars to me, while crossing your fingers and toes and then saying a few prayers and (of course), please share what you can.

THANK YOU for considering my request and for all the love sent my way!

story:
Bring Boy's Rites of Passage Programs to Ithaca!

My name is Pierce Walsh ....I have been a nature educator, working with youth in the Ithaca area for the last 12 years with Primitive Pursuits and Earth Arts.  My wife Jenny and I have two sons and a daughter. I feel it is incredibly important  to create a Nature-based rites of passage program, for boys, teens, and men. I believe that allowing the boys the opportunity to transition into manhood this way will feed back to the whole community and benefit us all.

Why Rites of Passage for Boys?

Stories form the fabric of our communities. We all want to have stories to tell -- stories of times when we acted bravely or wisely, amusing stories, poignant ones. Adolescent boys are no different -- for many, stories of tragedy narrowly-averted, or of challenges overcome are the ones they like to tell the most. "I got this scar when I....." In their lives, many teenage boys look for high-adrenaline situations that force them to walk up to the boundaries of convention to discover what might happen and how they will get through.

Once upon a time, when we lived closer to the land and closer together, the situations in which we lived provided young boys with just these types of challenges. Adolescents were called upon to hunt and to help protect the clan from dangerous animals or rival clans. The elder males of the clan mentored them in the particulars of adult responsibilities and, when they were ready, the elders presented them with guided challenges for them to overcome. These were their initiation rites -- their rites of passage into adulthood, that brought them not only into new roles in the clan, but also, a new sense of self. And sitting around the fire, they had the battlescars and stories to share.

In our modern lives, young boys don't have these important roles to play. We don't offer a place for them to put their hunter/warrior spirits to the test. We don't have important and adrenaline-filled tasks for them to fulfill, for the sake of feeding or protecting their families. But yet, they still have these spirits inside of them, and they still have the need to prove themselves and that need for stories to tell. It is no wonder many look to unsafe, unhealthy situations to meet some of this need. Such situations provide them with the exciting experiences and the stories they so crave.

But if the community provided them with nature-based survival challenges, if we gave them mentors who taught them wilderness skills and challenged them to push themselves to their limits, if we placed them in challenging and exciting yet safe, contolled situations that required them to use their skills, their intuitions, their minds, and their spirits, these would be their stories.

My goal, with this program is to create healthy outlets for that primal human need for powerful experiences, in a mentored context. During these programs, we can open the boys up to the possibility of exploring who they are and how they can use their wilderness skills and gifts in their proper place. The mentors and elders help them to process the experiences so that in the telling of the story, there are also the questions of what the experience taught them about a particular part of themselves, and about how it can translate to their lives and their community.We look to create a sensitivity and awareness in our boys so they can grow into who they are truly meant to be.

I am personally so grateful to my aunt Lydia and uncle Dan, who helped me have these kinds of opportunities in my life. If they had not stepped in to help me out of the rut I was finding myself in as a young teen, things would have been different. I am sure my life would not have been as rich, and full of meaning as it has been. I still love to tell the story of my face-off with a wolverine in Alaska, or the time my friends and I helped each other ford the raging stream, and of the ways in which my mentors guided me through and helped me know myself in ways I never would have!

You Can Help Make This Happen!

I am incredibly excited to bring this type of programming to the Ithaca area for the boys and men of our community. But I need your help!

The first step to getting this all started is for me to attend a Sacred Fire training workshop this month. In this workshop, with the guidance of mentors Michael Trotta of Sagefire Institute (www.sagefire.com), and Mark Morey of the Institute for Natural Learning (www.ifnaturallearning.com), I will experience, first hand, what the boys and men in our programs will experience.

The training and associated costs are $900. Every single donation helps, no matter how small! 

This small investment by our community will help get me on the road to being fully trained so I can begin working with our boys on this new frontier.

Anyone who donates $100 or more will be eligible to join the "Afternoon With Pierce in the Woods." For $50 or more, you can get your very own, hand-carved two-person bow drill kit with a link to an instructional video on making friction fires.

The Impact of these Programs is Real

Boys who participate in nature-based rites of passage:

  • Develop outdoor skills, self-confidence, and a strong sense of responsibility
  • Walk away with a stronger sense of who they are and what they have to contribute to their community
  • Allow them to test the limits of their skills and abilities so they can discover the tremendous resources they have inside themselves

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has money to contribute -- but there are other ways to help!

  • Please help us to get the word out about this fundraising campaign. The more people who know about it the better. 
  • Using the Indiegogo share tools, you can post it on your Facebook page or other social media platforms.

Thank you....I am so grateful for your help! We all benefit when our boys are mentored into manhood in a way that puts them in touch with the nature, their communities, and themselves!

story:
Help us publish this awesome book!

Rethinking Sexism, Gender, and Sexuality was born a few summers ago when Jody Sokolower, Rethinking Schools’ managing editor, and RS editor Melissa Bollow Tempel sat down in Jody’s kitchen to discuss an article Melissa was writing. “It's OK to Be Neither” is the story of Melissa’s growth as a teacher when Allie, a student who is gender nonconforming, joined her class. Until then, Melissa had not realized how customs like lining up by girls and boys could create problems for students who do not fit neatly into the female/male binary.

“It's OK to Be Neither” really struck a chord. As Melissa tells it, “We never dreamed it would be shared more than 45,000 times on one blog alone.” Allie is not unique. Gender nonconforming kids are in schools everywhere, and teachers want to know how to support them.

Gender identity is just one of many issues addressed in Rethinking Sexism, Gender, and Sexuality. The book includes sections on:

  • creating safe and nurturing classrooms
  • coming out at school as a teacher or student
  • integrating feminist and LGBTQ content into curriculum
  • moving beyond the classroom to school and community
  • teacher education

Want to check out a sample article or two?

Download these article PDFs for a sneak peek. 

  • “Queering Our Schools” editorial
  • “Standing Up for Tocarra”
  • “Character of Our Content”
  • “500 Square Feet of Respect: Queering a Study of the Criminal Justice System”

Jam-packed with thought-provoking articles by teachers, parents, and students

Jody and Melissa are working with three other wonderful editors—Kim Cosier in Milwaukee, Jeff Sapp in Los Angeles, and Rachel Harper in Chicago—and dozens of inspiring, dedicated teacher/writers. 

We know that Rethinking Sexism, Gender, and Sexuality will be an amazing resource for everyone working to change attitudes and strengthen communities so our schools will be safe and supportive places where all kids can learn. 

Support students, teachers, and families

Won’t it make you feel good to know that your dollars empowered a teacher to speak up in defense of a lesbian student at a staff meeting? Or supported a teacher as he decides whether to come out to his students? Or helped a big sister who pretends she doesn't know her gender nonconforming little brother? 

Your contributions will fund the production for this amazing book. That means copyediting, proofreading, and indexing; art direction and layout; printing and distribution.

Join our campaign today! Tell your friends!

Besides feeling good about making the world a better place, you can also earn some cool perks for donating: 

  • A sticker depicting our beautiful book cover
  • Subscriptions to our award-winning magazine
  • Copies of the book
  • Acknowledgement in the book of your generosity

See the sidebar for more details!

Meet Our Editors

Melissa Bollow Tempel (above) has taught in bilingual, dual language, foreign language, and university classrooms. Currently, she is the culturally responsive teacher leader for Milwaukee Public Schools. Melissa is also an editor and writer for Rethinking Schools. As an organizer with the Educators' Network for Social Justice, Melissa serves on the steering committee and planning team for the annual Anti-Racist/Anti-Bias Teaching Conference. Melissa and her husband live in Milwaukee and their mini-activist daughters attend La Escuela Fratney. Melissa spends her limited spare time sewing, knitting, cooking, eating, binge Netflixing, doing Crossfit, lifting heavy weights, and annoying her friends by incessantly muttering about the paleo lifestyle. 

Kim Cosier is a professor of art education and associate dean of the Peck School of the Arts at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. She believes in the power of art to create change in communities, and sees works of the imagination as central to building a better world. She is a member of Educator’s Network for Social Justice and enjoys stirring up trouble with Melissa Bollow Tempel and other activist teachers. She founded the Milwaukee Visionaries Project (MVP), an award-winning afterschool program for middle and high school students that teaches media literacy through production of video and animation. Kim lives in Milwaukee with her wife Josie and their dogs, Roger and Evie Mae.

Rachel Harper is an artist and educator in Chicago. Her work with pre-service and experienced teachers focuses on contemporary art as a vehicle for critically examining the social world, and for nourishing each teacher's creative practice. She is an activist with Teachers for Social Justice in Chicago and organizes community events about queer issues in education. Rachel teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago, where she is a doctoral candidate in curriculum studies, and explores art with people of all ages in the galleries of the Art Institute of Chicago and the Museum of Contemporary Art, where she leads the Teacher Institute. She also reviews family life and sexual health curricula for the Chicago Public Schools.

Jeff Sapp (above, right) is a professor of education at California State University Dominguez Hills in Carson, California. His research, focused on queer theory in regards to teacher education, has looked at how coming out as a teacher can be a transformative act in the learning community, at how queer teacher educators can guide queer pre-service teachers, as well as other teacher-related topics like an analysis of early childhood children's literature with queer themes.  To see his work, go to www.jeffsapp.com. Jeff lives in Long Beach, California, with his husband, Sino Donato, and their 5-year-old daughter Helena. An avid gardener, Jeff enjoys his hands full of dirt in the work of growing things. Daddy, Papa, and Helena are currently engaged in their first large vegetable garden.

Jody Sokolower is currently managing editor of Rethinking Schools. Before that, she developed curriculum for HIV test counselors, and taught middle and high school in Oakland, San Francisco, and Berkeley, California—most recently as a social studies teacher at Berkeley High. Jody has been working with teachers, parents, and kids on LGBTQ issues since her daughter Ericka was 10 months old, and has a long history as a political activist. She and her partner Karen have been together for 41 years.
story_txt:
Help us publish this awesome book!Rethinking Sexism, Gender, and Sexuality was born a few summers ago when Jody Sokolower, Rethinking Schools’
managing editor, and RS editor Melissa Bollow Tempel sat down in Jody’s kitchen
to discuss an article Melissa was writing. “It's OK to Be Neither” is the story
of Melissa’s growth as a teacher when Allie, a student who is gender nonconforming, joined her class. Until then, Melissa had not realized how customs like lining up by girls and boys could create problems for students who do not fit neatly into the female/male binary.


“It's OK to Be Neither” really struck a chord. As Melissa tells it, “We never dreamed it would be shared more than 45,000 times on one blog alone.” Allie is not unique. Gender nonconforming kids are in schools everywhere, and teachers want to know how to support them. Gender identity is just one of many issues
addressed in Rethinking Sexism, Gender,
and Sexuality. The book includes sections on:


creating safe and nurturing
classrooms


coming out at school as a teacher
or student


integrating feminist and LGBTQ
content into curriculum


moving beyond the classroom to
school and community


teacher education


Want to check out a sample article or two? Download these article PDFs for a sneak peek. 


“Queering Our Schools” editorial
“Standing Up for Tocarra”
“Character of Our Content”
“500 Square Feet of Respect: Queering a Study of the Criminal Justice System”

Jam-packed with thought-provoking articles by teachers, parents, and students

Jody and Melissa are working with three other
wonderful editors—Kim Cosier in Milwaukee, Jeff Sapp in Los Angeles, and Rachel Harper in Chicago—and dozens of
inspiring, dedicated teacher/writers. We know that Rethinking Sexism, Gender, and Sexuality will be an amazing
resource for everyone working to change attitudes and strengthen communities so
our schools will be safe and supportive places where all kids can learn. 
Support students, teachers, and families
Won’t it make you feel good to know that your dollars empowered
a teacher to speak up in defense of a lesbian student at a staff meeting? Or supported
a teacher as he decides whether to come out to his students? Or helped a big
sister who pretends she doesn't know her gender nonconforming little brother? Your contributions will fund the production for this amazing book. That means copyediting, proofreading, and indexing; art direction and layout; printing and distribution.
Join our campaign today! Tell your friends!
Besides feeling good about making the world a better place, you can also earn some cool perks for donating: 

A sticker depicting our beautiful book cover


Subscriptions to our award-winning magazine


Copies of the book


Acknowledgement in the book of your generosity

See the sidebar for more details!
Meet Our Editors
Melissa Bollow Tempel (above) has taught
in bilingual, dual language, foreign language, and university classrooms.
Currently, she is the culturally responsive teacher leader for Milwaukee
Public Schools. Melissa is also an editor and writer for Rethinking
Schools. As an organizer with the Educators' Network for Social Justice,
Melissa serves on the steering committee and planning team for the annual Anti-Racist/Anti-Bias Teaching Conference. Melissa and her husband live in
Milwaukee and their mini-activist daughters attend La Escuela
Fratney. Melissa spends her limited spare time sewing, knitting, cooking,
eating, binge Netflixing, doing Crossfit, lifting heavy weights, and annoying
her friends by incessantly muttering about the paleo lifestyle. Kim Cosier is a professor of art
education and associate dean of the Peck School of the Arts at the University
of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. She believes in the power of art to create change in
communities, and sees works of the imagination as central to building a better
world. She is a member of Educator’s Network for Social Justice and enjoys
stirring up trouble with Melissa Bollow Tempel and other activist teachers. She
founded the Milwaukee Visionaries Project (MVP), an award-winning afterschool
program for middle and high school students that teaches media literacy through
production of video and animation. Kim lives in Milwaukee with her wife Josie
and their dogs, Roger and Evie Mae.
Rachel Harper is an artist and
educator in Chicago. Her work with pre-service and experienced teachers focuses
on contemporary art as a vehicle for critically examining the social world, and
for nourishing each teacher's creative practice. She is an activist with Teachers
for Social Justice in Chicago and organizes community events about queer issues
in education. Rachel teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago, where she
is a doctoral candidate in curriculum studies, and explores art with people of
all ages in the galleries of the Art Institute of Chicago and the Museum of
Contemporary Art, where she leads the Teacher Institute. She also reviews
family life and sexual health curricula for the Chicago Public Schools.
Jeff Sapp (above, right) is a professor of education at California
State University Dominguez Hills in Carson, California. His research, focused
on queer theory in regards to teacher education, has looked at how coming out
as a teacher can be a transformative act in the learning community, at how
queer teacher educators can guide queer pre-service teachers, as well as other
teacher-related topics like an analysis of early childhood children's
literature with queer themes.  To see his work, go to www.jeffsapp.com. Jeff lives in Long
Beach, California, with his husband, Sino Donato, and their 5-year-old daughter
Helena. An avid gardener, Jeff enjoys his hands full of dirt in the work of
growing things. Daddy, Papa, and Helena are currently engaged in their first
large vegetable garden.
Jody Sokolower is currently managing editor
of Rethinking Schools. Before that, she developed curriculum for HIV test
counselors, and taught middle and high school in Oakland, San Francisco, and
Berkeley, California—most recently as a social studies teacher at Berkeley
High. Jody has been working with teachers, parents, and kids on LGBTQ issues
since her daughter Ericka was 10 months old, and has a long history as a
political activist. She and her partner Karen have been together for 41 years.

story:
Bonjour! 
My name is Danielle and I am about to Graduate from Florida Gulf Coast University with a Bachelors in Psychology.


I am passionate about helping children and have dedicated my life to supporting, educating and counseling children any way I can.

After enduring the death of my father at the age of 10 I was forced to mature fast and grow up quickly. I began putting others before my self and have developed into a very giving young lady. After this bump in my journey of life, I knew I wanted to help children like many did for me and become a trauma counselor. I am hoping to specialize in Grief and Bereavement Counseling and long to open my own practice complete with play, music and art therapy to assist children through all the traumas of life.


Some of you may be asking what this has to do with a trip to France and Spain. Not much except for the fact that Travel is another one of my passions. After graduating from Middle School in 2006 I became a People to People Student Ambassador and had the opportunity to travel to England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales. This was a HUGE step for me, leaving my mother and my little brother and taking part in a trip with no one I knew, and at the young age of just 16. Of course the trip ended up being amazing and I was able to learn so much about these countries in the short amount of time I was living there. By the end of the trip I yearned for more. As I entered high school I knew I wanted to take French classes so that one day I would be able to travel to France to live, learn, and explore. 

After 3 years of french classes in high school, as the French Honor Society President, I persuaded my teacher to take us on a trip to France. Excited and eager to put my french language to use I began planning for the trip. Sadly, the trip was quickly canceled due to the lack of participation from the other students. Although disappointed I continued on with my french language classes and became well versed by the end of high school.


Beginning college, I continued to study the french language. I have really developed a strong passion for not only the language but the culture as well. I am currently in my 3rd college level french class and loving every minute of it. I have searched for years to find a trip to join so that I may finally reach my dream of visiting France and getting to enhance my french language speaking skills. What better way to become fluent, then to immerse yourself in the culture and the language. 


My Trip!
This year my college is finally offering a trip to France and Spain. This trip focuses mostly on the food, wine, and hospitality aspects of the other countries. An AMAZING opportunity to explore the countries, and get a chance to taste what the countries have to offer.

I can think of nothing else but going on this trip and finally getting to see France and all that I have been studying for the last 6 plus years.

To do that I NEED YOUR HELP!
A trip like this is expensive. I will be doing the trip through the University as a summer class and will be there for two weeks. The total trip is over $4000 and I am unable to pay it without your help!

As I prepare for a trip like this, I can think of nothing but my future as I will enhance my knowledge, language and speaking skills. Thus one day, being so fluent in French that I won't only be able to help English speaking children, but French speaking children as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that sometimes money is not available to give. 
Would you please share my site with your friends and family? All donations will help and every dollar will get me that much closer to going on a trip that I have hoped for, for many many years.


MERCI! GRACIAS!

Thank you so much for your consideration and I look forward to sending you postcards from France and Spain!!

story:
A little about what I'm doing

Hi! I'm Dean Corona, and my greatest desire is to help our species evolve into a higher level of self awareness. 

I'm asking for help funding my first three months of two highly intensive courses centered around sex, desire, and using fear as a catalyst for personal growth. Both courses are put on by an organization called OneTaste, which itself is doing incredible work in the spreading of self awareness. I highly recommend searching out videos related to OneTaste and its founder Nicole Daedone on youtube. 

The first course is their Mastery program, which is a six month course on sex as a means for personal growth. My goal here is to shed the remainder of the shame I've held around sex, which so many of us allow to be a limiting factor in our lives.  

The second course is their coaching program. This is an innovative 10 month course designed to teach others to live a desire based life style. It is also designed to leave you with a functioning coaching business, limited only by your own desire. 


Here are a few links to tell you more about the courses, and OMing in general;

The Huffington Post did a great interview with Nicole Daedone and some of the OneTaste staff:

http://huff.lv/1crUoGo 

A link to the coaching program:

http://onetaste.us/coaching-program/

A link to Mastery:

http://onetaste.us/mastery-program/


What I need help with


What it comes down to is I need help funding my first three months. I work a full time day job, which I'm keeping for this period of time, to pay for living expenses. 

In order to continue my enrollment, I need to make a $1000 payment each month, per course, $2000 each month for tuition. 

The coaching program, which is the business creating aspect of the two, is being held in New York, and it will be the last of its kind taught by OneTaste. I live in California, and traveling to NY costs about $1000 round trip. This may end up costing less if I can buy a package deal, but funding will determine that for the time being. 

This means I need roughly $3000 each month for the next three months, for a total of $9000. 

I'm asking for help for the first three months because it is my goal to have a functioning coaching business by month four, which will pay the remaining $21000 of my tuition and traveling expenses. 

So I'm asking you to believe in me. Help me get started, and watch me run with this! I will give back to my community and to the rest of the world with your gifts!

The Impact

In this day and age, our fears are used as a tool for control. My desire is to empower people, to help them attain a higher level of self awareness so that they can take control of their fears, rather than allow themselves to be controlled. I want to share with the world how to live a life based on the unashamed pursuit of their desires. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Money isn't the only way you can help. I'll also be recording a video blog after each immersion, discussing anything from the topics covered, to issues I am personally addressing. You can help by subscribing to and sharing my youtube channel. You can tune in twice a month for a new video describing my journey!

I'll post a link to my channel as soon as I get my intro video up, so check back soon!

story:
Many of Our Students need your Help.

Hello,   I’m Gary McMullan and would like to welcome you to “Crosses for Cause”.  The cause that I am working toward is Agape Christian Academy, a non-profit private school in Corsicana, Texas.  Agape Christian Academy opened in 2008 after my wife had been homeschooling our daughter and some ohther kids in our home for several years.  When she had 53 kids and 5 theachers in our home, we recognized that there was a need for Christian education that wasn't being met in our town.  God led us to meet this need.  Our school is a 501 (c) 3 non profit and is accreditied br the National Association of Private Schools.  Learn more about Agape Christian Academy at www.agapecorsicana.org

Our students come from a wide variety of backgrounds.  Some families are able to pay their tuition without a problem, some families struggle every month, and some families just can't do it at all.  Many have been hit by hardships such as job loss, cancer, and divorce.  All need  the special love and guidence that they can't get in public school.  These are the children we are asking you to help.

One of the most surprising and unusual features of our school is that all of our teachers and administrators are volunteers.  They work, full-time, for no compensation except tuition for their children.  All tuition moneys are turned directly back to providing for our students.  We are simply a school on mission to share the love of Christ through education.

How You Can Help

Our primary goal is to raise funding for scholarships for 9 students.  Tuition and fees for one student run $3250 for the year, which makes our goal for all 9 students equal $29250.

In exchange for your donation of $30-$35 or more, you will receive a hand-crafted cross.  I began making these crosses as gifts for family and friends, and now I am making them to thank you for your sacrifice in helping these children.  All donations are tax deductable.

As a Christian, the cross is a reminder that Jesus suffered and died because of our sin, so that we could have eternal life.  John 3:16 says “For God so loved the world that he gave His one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life”.  Jesus was crucified as a sinner, stripped of his glory, and nailed to the cross as if he was a convict.   It is for this reason that I make most of my crosses roughed up.  Although they are made with great love, I don’t try to make them perfect.  Hand cut on a band saw and table saw, I don’t measure my cuts on purpose; I just “eyeball” the dimensions, fit and glue the cross piece to the upright.   I then use a small sanding drum to “rough up” the sides of the wood to resemble rough cut timbers, which I feel is how the original cross was.  Every piece of wood has a unique grain; I like to think of it as a “fingerprint” developed by the growth of the tree and all of the influences that effect its growth.  Each of the crosses is sprayed with a clear gloss finish that helps bring out the colors and gains of the wood and to protect from weather or turning dark.  I have also made a few one of a kind items like the three crosses above from mesquite which has a deep reddish brown color and is native to our area hear in central Texas.

For those of you who are feeling even more generous and able to support our cause, for a donation of $1000 or more, we will inscribe your name or the name of your loved one on our plaque of honor.  This plaque will recognize your selfless support of our ministry.

Finally, if you have been very blessed financially and moved by the mission of Agape Christian Academy, we will dedicate the building in your name or the name of your most loved one for a gift of $275,000.00 to pay off the building.  A 12x12 brass plaque will be placed by the front doors and the name placed on the front awning.

Why You Should Get Involved

The value of a Christian education cannot be taken for granted.  Public schools are able to provide for a child’s academic education, but cannot provide for a spiritual education.  Christian schools are able to fill this gap.  At Agape Christian Academy, children are immersed in a Christian environment, taught from a Christian worldview, and loved with the unconditional love of Christ.

Studies have shown that if a person does not accept Christ by the age of 18, there is a 94% probability that he never will.  In fact, 83% of all Christians make their decision to follow Christ between the ages of 4 and 14.  By supporting our ministry, you will help us to reach these children during this critical time period. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t give right now, you can help make a difference!  Here are some other ways to support us:

  • Pray, pray, pray!
  • Get the word out.  Share this campaign with your friends and encourage them to do the same!  Indiegogo has awesome share tools that make this super easy.

Studies have shown that if a person does not accept Christ by the age of 18, there is a 94% probability that he never will.  In fact, 83% of all Christians make their decision to follow Christ between the ages of 4 and 14.  By supporting our ministry, you will help us to reach these children during this critical time period.

Even if you can’t give right now, you can help make a difference!  Here are some other ways to support us:

Pray, pray, pray!
Get the word out.  Share this campaign with your friends and encourage them to do the same!  Indiegogo has awesome share tools that make this super easy.

story:
On my first day of preschool another child quickly placed the tower of blocks in my profile picture correctly.  He wanted to share and asked me to help, but I didn't know how....

 

My Story

Please help me to beat the odds and not be a negative statistic for FAS and prenatal drug abuse.

This is me when I was born.  My apgar score was only 1 and I needed lots of care.

My name is Evelynne and I am turning 4 years old this Summer!  My teenaged birth mom drank alcohol and used Meth Amphetamine, Cocaine, Marijuana and Tobacco when she was pregnant with me.  My mommy's placenta abrupted and I was born 6 weeks early and I was very sick.  The social workers took me away from my mom and I never had a chance to breast feed, so they fed me formula, but nobody knew I was allergic to cow protein.  Becuase my gastrointestional system was not developed I could not process the formula and when I was 2 months old I went into anaphylactic shock and my temperature dropped down to 95 degrees and I started bleeding out all my orifices.  I needed life support, and blood and plasma transfusions to survive and I had to stay in the hospital intensive care for over a month to get better.

Finally I was well enough to go home to my foster family, but the exposure to drugs and alcohol in utero and all the time it took me to get better when I was a baby has left me developmentally delayed.  I am pretty high functioning, but I need a lot of help to catch up to other kids my age so I can one day hope to function independantly in school without needing a teacher's aid and maybe go to university one day!

My Grandma and Grandpa take care of me now and they love me very much, but they don't have much money.  They put me in a montessori school for most of the year, but had to pull me out of school in April because they couldn't afford to keep making the payments to the school. 

My Grandparents would like to put me back in a montessori program in the Fall because this program works specifically on helping me develop the skills that I am delayed in and teaches me structure.  I have a very hard time focussing and sociallizing properly in groups so this environment is very important to develop my social skills too.  Montessori also allows me to learn at my own pace and treats me like the unique person I am.  My Grandparents want to give me the best advantage so that when I get to grade school I will be able to function just like the other kids do in a class and not be on a wait list for a teacher's aid.

Please help me go to a school that can help me develop all my skills.  I am almost 4, but I still can't say or read the whole alphabet or count/read numbers very well.  I still can't draw/copy simple shapes or write any letters either.  I need help with developing my motor skills and with my social development.  I know I can catch up to the other kids, but I just need a lot of extra help and a program that helps me with structure and developing all these skills I need for grade school.  I want to be the same as the other kids my age.

The doctor's are not sure how the exposure to drugs and alcohol in utero will affect me in the long term, so I need all the help I can get while I am little to help me grow strong and smart and do well in school and become an independant, productive member of society when I am all grown up.  These early years are so important to me.  Please help me have the best chance at life, because I am a great kid and every kid deserves a chance to learn and be the best they can be!

 

This is me when I was 2 months old in intesive care at Children's Hospital.

What We Need & What You Get

With your help you will know that you are helping me to get the best start that I can at life.  You give me the gift of early childhood education which will give me the best chance that I could ever have to grow and learn like other kids, to excel into my adulthood, and become a productive member of society who will help lead the way into the future alongside my peers, and to one day nuture my own children the best that I possibly can.  I already have the love and stability of my family.  All I need now is some help with my education during the most important learning years of my life!

 

  • $4500 Second preschool year tuition in Montesorri Program ($450 x 10 Months)
  • $200 Registration Fee
  • $200 School Uniform and Clothing for the year
  • $45 School Supplies

What Happens if Funds Fall Short or Exceed the Goal? 

If funding falls short it will be determined if there is enough to still send Evelynne to preschool even if it is just regular preschool.  It will depend on how much is raised to determine if it is enough to still send her to montessori, and if not if there is enough to send her to regular preschool.

If funds exceed the goal, funding will be put into drama classes for Evelynne as she has always been very animated, using all kinds of gestures, facial expressions, different tones to her voice, etc, since infancy.  She has a magnetic personality that captures people's attention and she has expressed an interest in taking drama.

If only a very small amount of money is raised and it isn't enough to commit to preschool, then those funds will be put towards some kind of creative classes for Evelynne at the community centre.  Could be dance, music or drama; whatever is offered at the time. 

 

The Impact

This is me in my last school.  I am very small compared to other kids my age.

You can't help me grow in size, but you can help me reach other developmental milestones!

 

The first 5 years of my life are the most crucial years of my development which will affect my ability to learn through grade school, will affect my physical health throughout life and impact my presence in community both socially and economically in future.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M89VFIk4D-s

 

"Early gains in school readiness due to early childhood education have been shown to have enormous positive economic and social impacts lasting well into adulthood, from higher educational attainment and less chance of involvement in criminal activity, to higher status employment and higher earnings (Schweinhart 2007; Sparling, Ramey and Ramey 2007.... Heckman concludes, "We cannot afford to postpone investing in children until they become adults, nor can we wait until they reach school age—a time when it may be too late to intervene. Learning is a dynamic process and is most effective when it begins at a young age and continues through to adulthood." (Heckman 2000, pg. 50)

"While no single curriculum or pedagogical approach can be identified as best, children who attend well-planned, high-quality ECE programs in which the curriculum aims are specified and integrated across domains tend to learn more and are better prepared to master the complex demands of formal schooling." (Bowman, Donovan and Burns 2001, p. 7-8)

Reference:

http://reap.stanford.edu/docs/early_childhood_education/

 

Why Montesorri?

"Dr. Maria Montessori was a doctor who worked with developmentally delayed children in Rome. She discovered that if she observed children she could discover much about what they needed in order to learn and flourish. Montessori was one of the first people to see the importance of observing children in order to plan an appropriate environment and curriculum to meet their needs....

Dr. Montessori identified four “planes of development,” with each stage having its own developmental characteristics and developmental challenges. The Early Childhood Montessori environment for children age three to six is designed to work with the “absorbent mind,” “sensitive periods,” and the tendencies of children at this stage of their development.

Learning that takes place during these years comes spontaneously without effort, leading children to enter the elementary classes with a clear, concrete sense of many abstract concepts. Montessori helps children to become self-motivated, self-disciplined, and to retain the sense of curiosity that so many children lose along the way in traditional classrooms. They tend to act with care and respect toward their environment and each other. They are able to work at their own pace and ability. The three-year Montessori experience tends to nurture a joy of learning that prepares them for further challenges."

Reference:

http://www.montessori.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=282:brief-answers-to-questions-parents-often-ask&catid=7:faqs&Itemid=25

 

 

I told mommy (grandma), my uniform was very special to me.  I really want to go back to school and learn!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Network to spread the word and give other's a chance to view and contribute to my campaign.
  • Use the SHARE tools on my campaign and other social networking.
  • Fundraising activities such as bake sales, garage sales, bottle drives....

 

A Word from my Grandma

When I was younger I was in foster care and at the age of 23 I became a mother.  My baby's father was abusive and I ended up a single mom.  The only person in the world I had to help me was a man I had met in my foster home and was like a dad to me.  This man ended up sexually abusing my child for years before she disclosed her abuse.  Despite many years of counselling my daughter was not able to cope with her abuse and she became addicted to drugs at the age of 12.

Please help me give every advantage I can to my granddaughter by helping with her early childhood education so she may overcome her developmental delays and reach the milestones she needs to succeed in grade school.  Please help me to give her the chance at life that my daughter never had.  My heart has already been so terribly broken and I need to do all that I can to ensure that Evelynne flourishes and has the happiest life ever!

I have been on disability for years since finding out what happened to my daughter as I still face many challenges with her addiction and not knowing where she is all the time... my husband is on his Canada Pension due to osteo arthritis and we also care for his adult daughter who is more severely developmentally delayed and unable to work.  Taking on Evelynne has been a huge additional expense for us and we just can't afford anything more than her basic care.

She is one very special little girl who has beat the odds so far, and has every opportunity to overcome her current disabilities if we just invest in her.

 

Grandma, Grandpa, Evelynne and Big Sister Marina during a Home Visit When She was Still in Foster Care.

 

Big sister Marina feeding Evelynne her Special Formula During her First Christmas!
story_txt:
On my first day of preschool another child quickly placed the tower of blocks in my profile picture correctly.  He wanted to share and asked me to help, but I didn't know how....
 
My Story
Please help me to beat the odds and not be a negative statistic for FAS and prenatal drug abuse.

This is me when I was born.  My apgar score was only 1 and I needed lots of care.
My name is Evelynne and I am turning 4 years old this Summer!  My teenaged birth mom drank alcohol and used Meth Amphetamine, Cocaine, Marijuana and Tobacco when she was pregnant with me.  My mommy's placenta abrupted and I was born 6 weeks early and I was very sick.  The social workers took me away from my mom and I never had a chance to breast feed, so they fed me formula, but nobody knew I was allergic to cow protein.  Becuase my gastrointestional system was not developed I could not process the formula and when I was 2 months old I went into anaphylactic shock and my temperature dropped down to 95 degrees and I started bleeding out all my orifices.  I needed life support, and blood and plasma transfusions to survive and I had to stay in the hospital intensive care for over a month to get better.
Finally I was well enough to go home to my foster family, but the exposure to drugs and alcohol in utero and all the time it took me to get better when I was a baby has left me developmentally delayed.  I am pretty high functioning, but I need a lot of help to catch up to other kids my age so I can one day hope to function independantly in school without needing a teacher's aid and maybe go to university one day!
My Grandma and Grandpa take care of me now and they love me very much, but they don't have much money.  They put me in a montessori school for most of the year, but had to pull me out of school in April because they couldn't afford to keep making the payments to the school. 
My Grandparents would like to put me back in a montessori program in the Fall because this program works specifically on helping me develop the skills that I am delayed in and teaches me structure.  I have a very hard time focussing and sociallizing properly in groups so this environment is very important to develop my social skills too.  Montessori also allows me to learn at my own pace and treats me like the unique person I am.  My Grandparents want to give me the best advantage so that when I get to grade school I will be able to function just like the other kids do in a class and not be on a wait list for a teacher's aid.
Please help me go to a school that can help me develop all my skills.  I am almost 4, but I still can't say or read the whole alphabet or count/read numbers very well.  I still can't draw/copy simple shapes or write any letters either.  I need help with developing my motor skills and with my social development.  I know I can catch up to the other kids, but I just need a lot of extra help and a program that helps me with structure and developing all these skills I need for grade school.  I want to be the same as the other kids my age.
The doctor's are not sure how the exposure to drugs and alcohol in utero will affect me in the long term, so I need all the help I can get while I am little to help me grow strong and smart and do well in school and become an independant, productive member of society when I am all grown up.  These early years are so important to me.  Please help me have the best chance at life, because I am a great kid and every kid deserves a chance to learn and be the best they can be!

$200 Registration Fee
$200 School Uniform and Clothing for the year
$45 School Supplies

If funding falls short it will be determined if there is enough to still send Evelynne to preschool even if it is just regular preschool.  It will depend on how much is raised to determine if it is enough to still send her to montessori, and if not if there is enough to send her to regular preschool.

Heckman concludes, "We cannot afford to postpone investing in children until they become adults, nor can we wait until they reach school age—a time when it may be too late to intervene. story:
Help us employ two New Haven city youth this summer! 

Youth Rights Media (YRM) is a New Haven, CT-based nonprofit dedicated to empowering youth to know, protect and advance their rights. YRM builds youth power and leadership by teaching media production and community organizing, equipping young people with tools, skills, and strategies for affecting change within themselves and their communities.

Youth Rights Media's Summer Institute program is an intensive, five-week program that employs 25 city youth. Young participants...

  • create media projects (like the one above!) that encourage youth voice, media literacy and civic participation;
  • engage in community conversations and are introduced to the theory and practice of community organizing;
  • create lasting relationships with peers and key community change-makers;
  • develop leadership and media production skills that will better position them for success in college and career.

We work with our funders, as well as other local organizations to employ 25 youth for 20-25 hours per week - but this year, we have two extra, dedicated students. Help us fund their summer positions! 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown:

  • Two awesome, committed young teens
  • 22 hours of work per week for 4 weeks
  • Minimum wage ($8.25 here in Connecticut!)

This equals $750 per youth employee, or $1,500 that we need your help in raising. Let's give these kids something safe, educational and fun to do this summer! 

Feeling generous? We've got swag - check out the perks on the right!

Your help will give two city youth a valuable and memorable experience this summer. 

Please consider making a donation to fund positions for these two youth. No amount is too small. 

If you're unable to contribute, have no fear - you can still support our youth by spreading the word about this campaign. Indiegogo provides some great tools for sharing! Direct friends and family here or to our website at www.YouthRightsMedia.org.

story:
Our Journey to Destination Imagination's Global Finals

"The Ivy REALM” has earned the honor to represent Washington at the Destination Imagination Globals Finals tournament -- THE WORLD’S LARGEST PROBLEM SOLVING COMPETITION AND CELEBRATION OF CREATIVE THINKING!

Since November 2012, these seven amazing Kirkland middle school students have brought their creative talents together to take on the Destination Imagination (DI) challenge, Twist-O-Rama.  In this structural challenge, the team:

  • Researched the properties of 18 possible materials for structure building
  • Engineered the lightest structure possible using at least 4 materials that would support the maximum amount of weight -- while also being twisted from the side by a battering ram
  • Created and performed a story that has an unexpected twist or surprising change
  • Integrated props and costumes they created from the same materials as the structure into their story

The Ivy REALM won the middle school level Seattle-Metro regional competition in March 2013, which allowed them to advance to the state tournament in Wenatchee to compete against other top-teams from across Washington.  The team continued to work to improve their performance and won first place at the State competition in April 2013 and were even recognized with the distinguished Renaissance Award for outstanding design, engineering, execution and performance.

100,000 students from 45 states, and 30 countries also competed at local and regional/state tournaments.  The Ivy REALM now have the very special opportunity to travel to the University of Tennessee in Knoxville and represent Washington to compete with the very best national and international finalists at the Destination Imagination Global Finals on May 22-25, 2013. 

All of this will be expensive and The Ivy REALM needs your help!

An Educational Opportunity of a Lifetime

Destination Imagination (DI), Inc. is a non-profit organization that helps kids around the world discover their creativity. DI creates programs that teach the creative process, so kids can solve problems in astonishing ways.  Kids build a lifelong confidence in working together to solve any challenge. In addition, the challenges teaches 21st century skills of the creative process from imagination to innovation and are aligned to National Education Standards, STEM standards, ELA Common Core Standards and Mathematics Common Core Standards.

This is an opportunity these students will remember forever. It will provide educational experience far outside the typical classroom. Interacting with children of the same age from all over the world while creating and sharing together will provide immeasurable understanding and compassion of different cultures.  It will nurture communication, team-building, and leadership skills.  Also, the kids practice and learn the the importance of goal setting, taking initiative, taking risks, time management, learning from mistakes and resilience. These are skills that will help these youngsters become tomorrow's leaders.

What We Need & What You Get

Each team member needs roughly $1000 to cover lodging, food and air travel.  This includes a registration package that consists of 16 meals, and 6 nights of housing at $685 per person on the University of Tennessee campus. Each team member will also have a $400 round trip airline ticket from Seattle to Tennessee. All other expenses will be out of our families’ pockets.  If we do not reach our goal, each family will need to pay the remaining costs.

Perks

For every donation of $25 or more, you will receive a personalized Thank You postcard from the Ivy REALM.

For every donation of $50 or more, you will receive an autographed team photo AND a Thank You postcard.

For every donation of $100 or more, you will receive a Washington Global Finals pin AND an autographed team photo AND a Thank You postcard.

Kirkland elementary school team also going to Global Finals!

The WinDInators, a team of Kirkland 5th graders are also going to Global Finals!  Two WinDInators are Ivy REALM siblings.  Both Kirkland DI teams are managed by Eileen Chen.  Please check out their Facebook fundraising page:

https://www.facebook.com/WindinatorsToGlobals

Can't Donate? Please Share Our Link

Every penny helps. If you aren't able to donate, but believe that this cause will help these seven children, please share our campaign with a friend or relative that you feel would support this ambitious group of youngsters to achieve their goal.

story:
About Me

My name is Leah Yared and I'm a high school sophomore in Rockville, Maryland. This summer, I will be going on a service trip to Zambia as a part of LearnServe International, a program that connects teenagers to the world.

Zambia is one of the poorest countries in the world. The average annual income is just $395. Zambia is also terribly affected by the HIV/AIDS crisis; 98,000 Zambians have died and 710,000 children are orphans - more than half of whom are HIV positive.

 

What I'll Be Doing

Our LearnServe Zambia team will focus on the HIV/AIDS crisis in Africa. We will work with:

 

  • Chikumbuso Women and Orphans Project

                           

  • World Bicycle Relief, building and bringing bicycles to health workers serving HIV/AIDS patients in rural Zambia

                 

 

  • Africa Directions, a youth-led group using drumming and dance as a medium to spread awareness about HIV/AIDS

  • Malambo Basic School, a rural school with limited resources but a desire to raise its children from poverty to independence

              

In addition, I will be bringing two 50 pound bags to Zambia that must be filled to the brim with donations. As a group, we will raise $5000 to cover direct project costs (like bike-building), so each participant must raise $250. If I raise at least $500, I will have enough money to cover the fundraising expectation and to buy needed items.

 

What We Need

Financial Fundraising Challenge

All donations will go to the following organizations:

  • Chikumbuso Community Center- Educates and supports orphaned and vulnerable children. Individual Goal: $25. Group Goal: $500.

  • Malambo Basic School- Educates rural children living at a farm school. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.

  • Africa Directions- Provides a safe haven for urban youth through drama and cultural activities. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.

  • Chitukuko School- Educates and supports orphaned and vulnerable children. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.
  • World Bicycle Relief- Provides bicycles to teachers and students who live more than 3 miles away from school. Bicycles provide access to healthcare, education, and economic development. They empower people, their families, and their communities. Cost and Individual Goal: $135 per bicycle. Group Goal: $2700.

---> The total amount I need to raise to donate to these specific projects is $250.

 

Material Fundraising Challenge

I also hope to raise money to pay for materials I'll pack with me in my 50 pound donations bag. With at least $250, I'll be able to buy most of the materials on this list. The more I raise, the more supplies can get sent over!

The Chikumbuso Community Center sponsors over 75 orphaned and volunerable children, costing about $450 per child per year. To support the orphans and the school, the following items are needed:

    • Toothbrushes
    • Toothpaste
    • Children's underwear/socks
    • Soap
    • Washcloths
    • Pencils (more expensive than pens!)
    • Erasers
    • Children's Vitamins
    • Backpacks (for children traveling to school)

The Malambo School, which has 275 students enrolled, is in need of school supplies to provide their students with the resources to succeed.

    • Scissors
    • Tape
    • Markers
    • Pen
    • Pencils
    • Pencil Sharpeners
    • Notebooks
    • Story Books
    • Art Supplies (crayons, paint kits, colored paper)

 

   The Impact

Any donation we receive will make a tremendous impact on the life of a Zambian child.

  1. Your donation will supply a child with a bicycle to get to school, saving him/her from walking miles every morning.
  2. Your donation will provide classrooms with necessary school supplies, equipping teachers with the resources to educate the next generation of Zambians.
  3. Your donation will provide a Zambian families with basic necessities that we take for granted here in the U.S., like toiletries and toothbrushes.
  4. Your donation will fund organizations that help spread awareness among youth about HIV/AIDS, which is one step towards ending the epidemic.

Any amount of money will help!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can still help us!

Please help me spread the word about this campaign by hitting the share/like button and forwarding this campaign's link on to friends/family!

 

 

 

**All photos were from the 2011 LearnServe Zambia trip blog and the LearnServe website.
story_txt:
About Me
My name is Leah Yared and I'm a high school sophomore in Rockville, Maryland. This summer, I will be going on a service trip to Zambia as a part of LearnServe International, a program that connects teenagers to the world.
Zambia is one of the poorest countries in the world. The average annual income is just $395. Zambia is also terribly affected by the HIV/AIDS crisis; 98,000 Zambians have died and 710,000 children are orphans - more than half of whom are HIV positive.
 
What I'll Be Doing
Our LearnServe Zambia team will focus on the HIV/AIDS crisis in Africa. We will work with:
 

Chikumbuso Women and Orphans Project

                           

World Bicycle Relief, building and bringing bicycles to health workers serving HIV/AIDS patients in rural Zambia

                 
 


Africa Directions, a youth-led group using drumming and dance as a medium to spread awareness about HIV/AIDS





Malambo Basic School, a rural school with limited resources but a desire to raise its children from poverty to independence


              
In addition, I will be bringing two 50 pound bags to Zambia that must be filled to the brim with donations. As a group, we will raise $5000 to cover direct project costs (like bike-building), so each participant must raise $250. If I raise at least $500, I will have enough money to cover the fundraising expectation and to buy needed items.
 


What We Need
Financial Fundraising Challenge
All donations will go to the following organizations:


Chikumbuso Community Center- Educates and supports orphaned and vulnerable children. Individual Goal: $25. Group Goal: $500.




Malambo Basic School- Educates rural children living at a farm school. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.


Africa Directions- Provides a safe haven for urban youth through drama and cultural activities. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.




Chitukuko School- Educates and supports orphaned and vulnerable children. Individual Goal: $30. Group Goal: $600.



World Bicycle Relief- Provides bicycles to teachers and students who live more than 3 miles away from school. Bicycles provide access to healthcare, education, and economic development. They empower people, their families, and their communities. Cost and Individual Goal: $135 per bicycle. Group Goal: $2700.


---> The total amount I need to raise to donate to these specific projects is $250.
 
Material Fundraising Challenge
I also hope to raise money to pay for materials I'll pack with me in my 50 pound donations bag. With at least $250, I'll be able to buy most of the materials on this list. The more I raise, the more supplies can get sent over!
The Chikumbuso Community Center sponsors over 75 orphaned and volunerable children, costing about $450 per child per year. To support the orphans and the school, the following items are needed:



Toothbrushes
Toothpaste
Children's underwear/socks
Soap
Washcloths
Pencils (more expensive than pens!)
Erasers
Children's Vitamins
Backpacks (for children traveling to school)



The Malambo School, which has 275 students enrolled, is in need of school supplies to provide their students with the resources to succeed.



Scissors
Tape
Markers
Pen
Pencils
Pencil Sharpeners
Notebooks
Story Books
Art Supplies (crayons, paint kits, colored paper)



 


   The Impact
Any donation we receive will make a tremendous impact on the life of a Zambian child.

Your donation will supply a child with a bicycle to get to school, saving him/her from walking miles every morning.
Your donation will provide classrooms with necessary school supplies, equipping teachers with the resources to educate the next generation of Zambians.
Your donation will provide a Zambian families with basic necessities that we take for granted here in the U.S., like toiletries and toothbrushes.
Your donation will fund organizations that help spread awareness among youth about HIV/AIDS, which is one step towards ending the epidemic.

Any amount of money will help!
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't donate, you can still help us!
Please help me spread the word about this campaign by hitting the share/like button and forwarding this campaign's link on to friends/family!
 
 
 
**All photos were from the 2011 LearnServe Zambia trip blog and the LearnServe website.

story:
Short Summary

The purpose of this project is simple. Attach a Raspberry Pi + camera module to a weather balloon and take photos from near space (+100,000ft). Why? Because it's educational, fun, and just because we can. Help us create a memorable experience, and donate the remaining funds to the local food bank!
 
My name is Seth Ludwig. I am the father of two children, and a loving husband. I started this project with one goal in mind, to create a memorable and educational project for everyone involved. This is important to me because I've always enjoyed learning, experimenting, and doing things out of the ordinary. It is my intention to include the surrounding community, local schools, friends, and family members in this project. Anyone interested is welcome to attend.
 
By funding this project, you are directly contributing to the education of students and children, the research of my team, the enjoyment of all participants, and putting food into the bellies of those less fortunate. Choose one of our perks, and be rewarded for your donation!

We have raised over $650 USD for the local food bank, with the help of our contributors. Our project has already been bought and paid for. With your help, we can truly make a difference in the lives of those who are less fortunate.

You're Completely Funded, Now what?

You can still help us make a difference by donating to this campaign, or sharing it with your friends. We've already set aside over $650 USD from this fundraiser to be donated to the local food bank, and any additional funds raised will be added to the donation. Lets show the world what we are capable of doing!

Updates

July 7: The payload design has been completed, cameras have been mounted, sealed, and implemented. Testing will continue, check the facebook page for photo updates!

July 2: Laura Blasey, from the Frederick News Post, wrote a great article on the project! You can read it here.

June 29: Payload container will be designed and built by the team next week. Stay tuned for photo updates!

June 26: Battery containers have arrived. Combined with voltage regulators, we are ready to launch in August! Testing will continue. Updates will follow!

June 24: All parts have been recieved, with the exception of our battery containers. Contacted a helium provider and reserved a 125 cu. feet tank for early August. Who knew that there is apparently a helium shortage?

June 21: Parts are being shipped out. Parachute, radar reflector, voltage regulators, and LED flashers have all arrived and are functioning properly. Expect more updates next week!

June 20: Using a 1 second interval for 20 minutes, here is a timelapse video that was compiled using the Raspberry Pi and Camera Module once the rain had cleared.

June 19: The generousity of everyone has been extraordinary. We have surpassed our goal, and still have plenty of time left for the fundraiser! Last night I configured and tested the camera module creating a timelapse video sample, check it out.

June 18: We've reached our goal! Thank you to everyone who has contributed so far, without you this project would not be possible! You can still donate and recieve perks, until July 24th. Thanks again guys!

June 16: The team did a little more research on desirable launch sites for the project, and we've settled on the Denton, MD area.

June 15: GPS module arrived today. It is functioning flawlessly! Keep up to date with all recent developments as they happen at our facebook page.

June 14: Raspberry Pi units showed up today, and so did the weather balloon! This really only means that less money will be spent on the project hardware requirements, and more will be donated to the food bank. Thanks for your continued support of this project!


FrederickWeek.com has agreed to host you as a speaker on their show if you make a donation to this fundraiser.

What We Need & What You Get

With the success of our campaign, we don't really need much other than your support. Our project has been paid for and testing is ongoing. All additional funds raised by this project are being donated to the local food bank. 

The components required for this project are as follows:

  1. Raspberry Pi (x2) - Verticle and Horizontal imagery.
  2. Raspberry Pi Camera Module (x2) - Verticle and Horizontal imagery.
  3. 4GB SD Card (x2) - Storage of the images on each Raspberry Pi
  4. Weather Balloon - We're currently looking at a 20ft dia. Professional Weather Balloon, 600g.
  5. Parachute - Low porosity rip-stop weather balloon parachutes are designed for high altitude payloads. To ensure the safety of both the people involved, and our payload's safe return, this is a critical component of our project. The parachute will be tested extensively prior to launch. We need a parachute approximately 5-6ft in diameter to meet the requirements of our payload with a safe descent rate.
  6. GPS Tracker - We're currently looking at the Garmin GTU-10 for the recovery of our equipment.
  7. Lithium Batteries - Lithium batteries are designed to withstand extreme temperatures, which are prevalent in the upper stratosphere. For our project, we intend to use Energizer's Ultimate Lithium batteries with a USB battery pack to provide power to our equipment.
  8. Helium Tank / Gas Rental

Balloon Flight Theory

  1. A payload (an insulated box containing some electronics such as a GPS and a radio to allow you to follow progress) is attached to a balloon which is filled with helium (He).
  2. The balloon is released and, as He is lighter than air, the balloon rises and pulls the payload with it.
  3. As the balloon rises the outside pressure decreases which leads to the helium inside the balloon expanding (imagine like its expanding to fill the gap as the outside pressure decreases), this causes the balloon to stretch.
  4. The balloon is made of a form of latex and is incredibly stretchy however it gets to a point where it can't stretch any more and bursts.
  5. Now that there isn't any upward pull from the balloon the payload begins to fall to earth pulled by gravity, as it falls the parachute opens up slowing its descent and it gently glides down to earth.
  6. Throughout the flight the GPS unit inside the payload container is transmitting its position to the internet, where it is viewed by the ground team and tracked.
  7. Additional components include for example cameras and temperature sensor. You also will need a parachute, a balloon and some helium and permission to launch.

Resources used for the planning of this project:

  1. Planning: http://stilldavid.com/habfaq/
  2. Flight Trajectory: http://weather.uwyo.edu/polar/balloon_traj.html
  3. Recovery: http://the-rocketman.com/recovery.html
  4. Additional information: http://kaymontballoons.com/Near_Space_Photograp...

As a special thanks to contributors involved in funding this project, here is what you can expect to get by making a donation:

$5 donation: By donating five dollars to this project, you will receive a personal thank you posted to the credits of the blog post!

$10 donation: By donating ten dollars to this project, you will receive five of the highest quality photos taken during the flight, as well as a personal thank you posted to the credits of the blog post! Delivery is via digital download or email.

$25 donation: By donating twenty-five dollars to this project, you will receive all of the photos taken during the flight, as well as a personal thank you posted to the credits of the blog post! Delivery is via digital download or email.

$100 donation: By donating one hundred dollars to this project, you will receive a video documentary recorded during launch and recovery, all of the photos, as well as a personal thank you posted to the credits of the blog post! Delivery is via digital download or email.

$150 donation: By donating one hundred fifty dollars to this project, you will receive one of the Raspberry Pi units used in the flight, a video documentary recorded during launch and recovery, all of the photos, as well as a personal thank you posted to the credits of the blog post! Delivery is via digital download or email for the photos, and priority USPS shipping for the Raspberry Pi unit.

In the event that we are unable to recover the payload or in the event that the launch does not go as planned or fails, all contributors will recieve the launch footage free of charge (to verify that we actually tried), and free photos and video for the next launch.

The Impact

Your contributions to this project are directly creating educational and lasting memories for children of all ages. Again, any funds remaining at the end of this project are to be donated to the Thurmont Food Bank, to help feed the homeless or less fortunate. Thank you for your contribution!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help but are unable to support our project financially, we understand. You can still help us out by sharing this project with your family, friends, or coworkers. Share it on Facebook, tweet it on twitter, let people know what we are about!

story:
(All new perks as of 4/15)

** note from Lawrence Polsky - the guy who started this page

I started this page because I so strongly believe in helping Louis – he is a great guy who has helped me a lot, very generously over the past year.  It is just so amazing to me that he just lives down the street and is running with me and coaching me for free..  He has become a friend.  20 years my junior, but still.  I want to give back.  I am inspired by the determination he has to get to the Olympics.  

It started when he was 5years old: Louis ran 1 mile  to school, and back, on his first day.  He was #1 in the US for 800m (1/2 mile) in high school.  In college, he was NCAA Conference Champion in 10K Cross Country.  He was top ranked US Sprint distance triathlete in 2011, competed in Beijing at International Finals and was 7th in world in his age group . Now he moves to the next level as he moves to Colorado in May to  take his training hard core.

He works 2 jobs.  Trains extensively. And has a dream that is reachable. His family is totally behind him, letting him live at home.  He has a coach that has coached others to be Olympic Triathletes.  He’s got everything.  He could just use some help financing the many things he needs to keep moving forward.   

I have most of this info on thid fundraiser page, as well as a video in the gallery section of a short 2 minute interview I did of him where he talks about WHY he wants to be in the Olympics

Thank you to all who have generously gotten us this far.

We would  love to have YOU on Team Tutti before the May 1 end of the fundraiser!

 

**************

I am sure at some point you have dreamed of that Olympic moment.  You know, where you see yourself in the Olympics.  The glory. The fanfare.  In your mind’s eye at least. 

Louis has this dream.  But Louis' dream is a little different than yours or mine.

He has a shot.  A real shot at winning the gold.

It's the typical American story: talent, a dream,  hard work.  The path to the Olympics is a hard one.  Like all our paths.   There are no sponsors that drop out of the sky (not until he wins in the Olympics). There are no specialized facilities.  There are no days off. 

Join Team Tutti (Louis' nickname which appropriately means 'all together')

Louis is doing it on his own.  Relentlessly. Daily.  Hourly.  As he says "you just have ignore the pain.  Just push on when your mind says no more."

But he can't do it without the necessary tools for success.  Running shoes. Racing uniform. Tires. Bike repairs.  Travel costs. And the like.

He works like all of us.  2 jobs.  Working to make money.  Working to make it to the Olympics.

Typical Day for Louis:

* Wake up at 5am. Workout. Run or Bike.

* Leave for his work - this month he is remodeling his grandmother's kitchen (he went to school for architecture)

* Spend a few afternoon taking care of neighbors kids as part of a day-care.

* Find some time to work on his new sport drink, Kimbia Chai, which he just got into Whole Foods

* 5pm Workout again.  If it is a swim, that starts at 8pm when pool opens.

* Relax with friends once a week if time.

* Get up and do it again.

 

His hard work is paying off.  So he is taking it to the next level.  He is moving to Colorado in May to be near his coach and train hard core.

Support Louis in making his Olympic dream, and your Olympic dream, a reality.  When he goes, we all go.  When we support his dream, we say "I believe".  "I believe in dreams. I believe in hard work. I believe in perseverance. I believe that we can tap into our talents and push ourselves to be best." 

Help fund the dream. Louis will make your donation into gold. Literally.

 

With 2008 Gold Medalists (Jan Frodeno, Louis, and Emma Snowsill)

About Louis:

* Born, raised and still lives in the same town: Warwick,NY

* Was top runner in high school  - several records including Nike Outdoor National Champion

* Went to college and studied Architecture.  (he’s no dummy and very handy)

* NCAA Conference Champion in college

* He is a vegetarian. 

* With the love and support of his parents, he lives at home.  In return he must take care of the house and is volunteered for family stuff like remodeling his Grandmother’s kitchen is his spare time!

* Is moving to Colorado end of May to train with other Olympic hopefuls and be closer to his coach.


 


                              Visualizing Success
